div.h3: What is the purpose of the study?
div.p: We are working on developing a system to automatically detect misinformation from counterfactual claims in the domain of climate change. In this study, human participants will be needed to annotate selected Reddit claims with their truth values, to generate training data for the misinformation detection system. This annotation will be done via public platforms, i.e., Amazon Mechanical Turk, which protects participants' personal information. During the annotation, participants will give truth values using a web App that we wrote, which does not collect any personal information.
div.h3: Why have I been asked to take part?
div.p: You have been asked to take part because you choose to annoate our data via Amazon Mechanical Turk.
div.h3: Do I have to take part?
div.p: No – participation in this study is entirely up to you. You can stop and at any time, without giving a reason. In our study, no personal data will be asked or touched in any way. We will only use the truth values that you labelled for the purpose of this study. Your rights will not be affected. If you wish to withdraw, contact the PI. We will keep copies of your original consent, and of your withdrawal request.
div.h3: What will happen if I decide to take part?
div.p: That means you have read this consent and are happy with it. Then you will be given the data as pairs of an antecedent and a consequence via this web App, of which you will assign the truth values and choose whether an antecedent entails its consequence. You can stop at any time and the labels you’ve given will be recorded and saved by the web App, which are the only data that we will collect. Compensation. You will be paid for your participation in this study via Amazon Mechanical Turk.
div.h3: Are there any risks associated with taking part?
div.p: There are no significant risks associated with participation.
div.h3: Are there any benefits associated with taking part?
div.p: Yes, you will be paid for your participation.
div.h3: What will happen to the results of this study?
div.p: As there will be no personal information involved in the data annotation, the results of this study may be summarised in published articles, reports and presentations.

Your data will be processed in accordance with Data Protection Law. There will be no personal information about you in this study. All electronic data will be stored on a password-protected encrypted computer, on the School of Informatics’ secure file servers, or on the University’s secure encrypted cloud storage services (DataShare, ownCloud, or Sharepoint) and all paper records will be stored in a locked filing cabinet in the PI’s office. Your consent information will be kept separately from your responses in order to minimise risk.

div.p: The University of Edinburgh is a Data Controller for the information you provide. You have the right to access information held about you. Your right of access can be exercised in accordance Data Protection Law. You also have other rights including rights of correction, erasure and objection. crowd-tab.div:
What are conditional claims?
A conditional claim consists of a condition and a conclusion. It often takes the form of 'If P, then Q'. GIVE FAMILIER EXAMPLE. P is the condition, and Q is the conclusion. The condition is a set of circumstances that, if true, result in the conclusion. The example below is a conditional.
if Natalia had left at 10 a.m. yesterday, she would have arrived on time.
If it rains tomorrow, then I am going to wear my boots.
Unless I get an offer tomorrow, I will take a vacation as a break.
Speaker's belief
The speaker of a conditional claim may indicate that they believe that the condition is not satisfied in reality i.e. it is not true. For instance, in the first example above, the speaker indicates that Natalia did not leave at 10 am - they believe that the condition is not true.
However, this is not the case for every conditional claim. In the claim: 'If Natalia departed at 10 a.m. yesterday, she will attend the meeting this afternoon', the speaker believes the condition might be true. It is implied that they believe it is possible that Natalia departed at 10 a.m. yesterday.
The same applies to the conclusion. The speaker may believe the conclusion is not true, or they may believe that the conclusion might be true.
Is a claim verifiable?
Verifiable claims describe statements that can be proven true or false using facts, e.g., the following claim is verifiable and it is true: New York is the capital city of the US.
Non-verifiable claims are neither true nor false. They express a belief, attitude, value, judgment, or feeling, e.g., dogs are the best mammals in existence or World War II was a terrible war. According to Mometrix, "the claim—“World War II was a terrible war”—strikes many of us as factual. However, this is an opinion... It is very rare for a claim with a value word like “terrible” to be factual."
Is it true? A verifiable claim can be true or false. As everyone has a limit to their knowledge, it's possible that we know a claim is verifiable, e.g., a capital city of a country, but we do not know the answer. Thus, there will be an option of 'I don't know' to choose in this annotation.
Does a conclusion follow its condition?
A conclusion Q follows its condition P, if P causes Q. Thus, when P happens, Q will happen as a result.
